September 2nd

Seven-thirty a.m.

 

Dear Diary,

 

Woke up. Discovered I am definitely still me. Promptly attempted suicide by pillow.

 

Failed dismally, which did frankly nothing for my outlook.

 

As an additional reason for living, I realised I am also beginning to smell like the pack animal whose nose I so recently envied last night in the lift.

 

I need a bath, badly. I will, however, attempt to waste at least half an hour more sorting out my school uniform, organising my book-bag, memorising my own time-table, getting a start on unpacking the old travelling trunk — any excuse available to me for not leaving my room just yet.

 

Thirty minutes should be enough, shouldn’t it, for Malfoy to perfect his coif? Or whatever it is boys do in the bath when they’re alone, I am sure I am too delicate to know?

 

Despite the fact I cannot even consider showing my face at breakfast without a good scourging, this desire to be clean is infinitely outweighed by another, far more immediate desire.

 

Namely, to ensure at all costs that I never, ever again encounter Draco Malfoy on my way into or out of the loo. Our loo. Oh no, I’ve made myself really ill now.

 

Or worse still! What if he knocks at the door while I am still on the loo? The very idea oh heavens me I think I can feel a brain hemorrhage coming on…

 

~*~

 

Seven-thirty-six a.m.

 

Well, no, on second thought, I don’t suppose that does really sound like something Malfoy would do, does it? Bothering to knock first, I mean?

 

Common courtesy is not a precept that has managed to penetrate a skull so thickly encrusted with hair product as his.

 

Probably he would become affronted at encountering a locked door, kick said offending door in, and go about his ablutions while ignoring my pantsless presence entirely. Probably he would use me as a towel rack.

 

Though, taking into consideration Malfoy’s past opinions of me — ranging anywhere between “boot slime” to “soiled army hospital bandage” — ranking as “furniture” is probably a fair step up. Implying I have any functionality at all is a huge compliment, looking at it that way.

 

Golly.

 

At any rate, I refuse to let myself suffer a repeat of last night’s incident. Possibly I shall suggest we go on a bath-time rota, just to make it really official and proper. Possibly he will not ridicule me mercilessly if I do.

 

Bother, bother, bother… maybe I can find some dust-bunnies to push about.

 

~*~

 

Eight-ten a.m.

 

For Christ’s sake. Malfoy still hasn’t left the bathroom, he had better not be having a marathon wank.

 

I am going to have to risk it. I shall just poke my head out of the door and if there are no startling apparitions within the immediate vicinity, I will venture some steps further out into the common room.

 

From there on, who can really tell?

 

~*~

 

Eight-eleven a.m.

 

Oh sod the entire blasted thing, Malfoy’s not even here!

 

I have wasted all this time and my Po pyjamas still smell like stressed-out camel and there are nineteen minutes before I have to be downstairs for breakfast and Malfoy was never even here.

 

I appear to have underestimated Draco Malfoy’s cunning. Clearly he has got an agenda all his own. Though if Malfoy wants to wake up ridiculously early just so he won’t have to speak an unnecessary word to me, that is his prerogative entirely.

 

I mean, honestly. The mad, stupid things some people will do to avoid others.

 

~*~

 

Eight-thirty-two a.m.

 

Fastest shower of my life, followed by a very accurate leap into my clothing, and then I was rushing down the hallway to the lift box.

 

As I ran, I twisted my damp hair into a plait down one side of my head, because as it turns out it’s hard to do anything symmetrically with an extremely heavy book-bag hanging off one arm.

 

I wasn’t over bothered, because it is hair, and, well, that’s all really. In my fourth year I simply started using conditioner as well as shampoo, and this seems to have covered all the necessary bases since, frizz-wise.

 

A fresh new horror washed over me as I drew level with the lift doors. How in the name of Lucifer’s shorts was I to get back downstairs? Filch and McGonagall both had failed utterly to mention this part to me last night, when it might have done me some good.

 

I glanced at the portrait to the right-hand side of the lift doors. It was surrounded by a rather garish gold frame and on the canvas were painted three toga-clad young women — Nymphs, probably — attempting to ensnare a rather handsome, olive-skinned gentleman with some tree vines. He was putting up a good fight, though still a losing one if his artfully torn clothes were anything to go by.

 

“I expect he figured it out straight away,” I said aloud conversationally, trying to keep the bitterness out of my voice. Malfoy’s stranded corpse was certainly nowhere to be seen, slumped pitifully against a nearby wall or otherwise.

 

One of the Nymphs — right away I mentally dubbed her as ‘the one that looks like a Bernadette’ — tugged hard on her section of vine, sending the young man careening backwards into a patch of thick green moss. She flashed a wicked, knowing grin at me.

 

“Wasn’t as quick as all that, was it, sisters?”

 

“Oh, gracious, no,” concurred the ginger one — Maggie — wiping from her brow the honest sweat of exertion as she propped a heel on a nearby log. “Took him at least a quarter of an hour. ‘Course, most of that was spent just staring and staring and staring...”

 

“His eyes do sort of smoulder when he concentrates, don’t they?” observed the blonde, Anastasia, dreamily.

 

I forced my features out of the dirty look they were on the verge of forming, and instead returned my attention back to the lift doors, wood-panelled like the interior of the box, and otherwise completely unremarkable.

 

I tried the dormitory password, but that did not seem to have the same astonishing effect as on the way up. I felt for invisible seams or levers or buttons and turned up nothing. I knocked carefully up and down the panels, in case one sounded particularly hollow, indicating — I don’t know what. A panel that hid a switchboard or a helpful little gnome or something.

 

“She has got rather a more hands-on approach than the other one, wouldn’t you say?” Anastasia commented in her breathy, blissful voice, apparently addressing their olive-skinned captive now. She was certainly stroking his dark curly hair rather attentively.

 

He rattled something off in very rapid Greek, looking at me in wide-eyed appeal.

 

I shrugged as if to impress upon him that he was on his own with this one, mate, and went back to studying the doors.

 

Right, I thought to myself, let us revisit what we know. Lifts in the Muggle world are hailed by pressing buttons: one for up, one for down. As simple as that. The more complicated bits are sorted out later, namely once you’ve managed to get inside one of the bloody things.

 

Essentially, the symbols that traditionally represent ‘up’ or ‘down’ are always mirror opposites of each other. Usually arrows, one each pointing in their respective directions. So if the ‘up’ arrow is like so, then by default the ‘down’ arrow must be —

 

“’Root of iris’?” I hedged doubtfully, and, when nothing happened: “Or…  just ‘root iris’?”

 

There was the distant rattle of a counterweight in immediate response, and my stomach fluttered pleasantly at this small but significant success. I had worked out how to leave my own dormitory! A sound victory for all and a feather in my cap, no argument there!

 

“Ooh, look, she’s done it!” enthused Anastasia, executing a sailor’s knot around their captive’s ankles with a length of vine and terrifying efficiency.

 

“I say, well done, you,” commended Maggie.

 

“Wasn’t much of a stretch, though, was it?” Bernadette remarked, pretty brow wrinkling, “not if you think about — “

 

“You’re all too kind,” I interjected with quiet dignity, before stepping triumphantly into the lift box.

 

~*~

Eleven-thirty-four p.m.

 

Finally, finally, after what seemed an age, the lift shuddered to a stop. Malfoy strode out into the hallway beyond without a glance back at me, and at last I felt it was safe to breathe again.

 

Camels, I feel, have got it spot on.

 

Evolution has given them cleverly-designed nostrils which they can open and close at will, to defend against all variety of nasal assaults (and the only reason I cannot safely say that Draco Malfoy’s cologne is less dangerous than a desert sandstorm is because I have never been in a desert sandstorm. Awfully exfoliating, I should imagine.)

 

My nostrils, as it happened, were feeling especially vulnerable just then.

 

It’s not fair that a boy should smell nicer than you, is it? There has got to be a rule somewhere about these types of standards… some kind of pie chart on the subject. What use are global statistics studies if nobody’s going to do any on the important things in life?

 

Is this my fault? Am I not maintaining my femininity properly? Oh, gracious, there goes my self-esteem again.

 

I stepped glumly out of the lift box, watching in mild interest as wood-panelled doors closed over it again. I heard an almighty groan and assumed the box must have begun its rattling descent back down to the broom cupboard. How would it know, I wondered, when we wanted to leave again?

 

The worrying notion that I may be trapped up here with Draco Malfoy ‘til we finally succumbed to starvation or, more likely, ate each other, followed me all the way down the short hallway (that looked much like any other hallway in the castle), and to the door at the end.

 

Malfoy was already through it and out of sight by the time I reached it. At least he’d left the door standing open, rather than slam it in my face. Manners, you know.

 

I shut it silently behind me and surveyed the common area.

 

It was fairly standard as common rooms go, but it did look comfortable. Two large, overstuffed couches with a low, square trestle-table between them. To one side, a stone grate large enough to stand upright in; a bureau and row of wall-mounted cupboards to the other. Four doors, including the entrance, led off the common room; all doors but one, the one directly across from the entrance, were currently closed. The room’s colours were generic, denoting none of Hogwarts’ four houses; dark-stained wood, stone, and burgundy accents.

 

Not the sunniest of places, but neither is the rest of Hogwarts castle, come to that. Admittedly, the fact it was night-time might have had an influence on things.

 

Malfoy came out of the door which was standing half-open, then, apparently satisfied with his initial inspection of the room within. He ignored me completely, stalking past me to try the door on the far left instead.

 

Curious, I peered inside the room he’d just vacated. Ah. The notorious Shared Loo. The toilet was a subtle hint.

 

Ten seconds later, Malfoy was stalking past me again, headed now for the final unopened door on my right.

 

He jerked his chin back over his shoulder, smirking. “I think that one’s yours.”

 

My stomach bottomed out in horror. I opened my mouth to demand to know what horrible thing he’d done to it, but he had already disappeared inside what was, by process of elimination, his bedroom. The door banged shut behind him, effectively cutting off any opportunity for conversation.

 

I dashed across the common room in a panic, flinging open the door to (allegedly) my room.

 

~*~

 

Eleven-thirty-nine p.m.  

 

I find myself comforted by the simple fact that today is nearly over. Tomorrow has got to be better, because once you’ve hit bottom there’s simply nowhere else to go but up, right?

 

Right?

 

There were no venomous snakes, dead rodents, or indeed any telltale sounds or odours at all waiting for me when I cautiously entered my new bedroom for the first time.

 

I rushed to the bed. No spiders or scorpions or severed horse heads under the bedcovers.

 

I cast my gaze around, squinting in the dim moonlight. No rude words scrawled on the walls in indelible, glow-in-the-dark ink. He hadn’t even tracked mud on the carpet.

 

Fine, so my imagination had had rather a go of it in the short time it took me to get from the middle of the common room to my bedroom door. But my imagination also knows precisely what Draco Malfoy is capable of.

 

All I had to do was switch on the desk lamp, however, to realise what made Malfoy so certain this room was mine.

 

Mum had insisted last-minute that I pack extra clothes to keep as reserves; she claimed to be concerned by how far the standards of laundry service at Hogwarts had fallen since my first year (mention a sock going missing one time, and this is what you end up with…) One should not have to compromise one’s personal standards, she said. One can never be too prepared, she said.

 

I never did get clarification on what school-wide disaster she foresaw me needing to be prepared for (even if the castle falls under siege, at least I’ll always have clean knickers!); but I could nevertheless appreciate the gesture. She is my Mum, after all.

 

Still, I mused philosophically, the Teletubbies pyjamas weren’t my favourite.

 

I picked them up from the foot of my bed with a sigh, face burning hotly. One of the house-elves must have laid them out for me on the assumption that, simply because they’d been packed last in my trunk, these were the ones I intended to wear tonight.

 

Note to self: record this event in S.P.E.W. campaign folder, under heading, ‘HERE IS WHY.’

 

~*~

 

Eleven-forty p.m.

 

All right, so the wall-size tapestry of Godric Gryffindor riding a dragon might, even to the casual observer, have been a slight tip-off...

 

~*~

 

Midnight

 

I have decided to throw all caution to the wind and wear the damn pyjamas anyway.

 

My rebellious side, which I so rarely bother with, is getting a real airing on this fine First Night Back. Malfoy thought I would be embarrassed? Ha! He could take his knowing smirk and sit on it.

 

Although the bum-flap with Po’s face on doesn’t cheer me up quite as much as it used to, I am sad to discover. Nor do I recall it ever fitting so tight.

 

I was forced to sit down with a certain amount of care.

 

Malfoy strode out of his room about twenty minutes later, a towel slung around his neck. Trousers and an un-tucked Oxford shirt were all that remained of his uniform.

 

He came up short when he spotted me sitting on one of the couches, my work spread out on the low table in front of me.

 

To my intense annoyance, he didn’t even mention my attire.

 

“You realise it’s gone midnight.” Not a question, but a statement. As if he only wished to validate for himself what he’s suspected all along, that I truly am insane and ought to be committed for the public benefit.

 

Which should have been my warning right there, because since when has Malfoy ever given a flying toss about ‘the public benefit’?

 

“I can tell time, Malfoy,” I replied mildly, dipping my quill and pulling the next timetable towards me.

 

He narrowed his eyes at me a moment, then continued on to the bathroom without another word. He shut the door behind him with a snap. A few seconds later, I heard the squeak of spigots turning and the muffled roar of gushing water.

 

Minutes passed. The taps turned off. There was silence on the other side of the door.

 

I dropped my chin onto my palm in consternation, studying the timetable before me. This one was taking Astronomy their first year? Tricky, that…

 

“I know I’m going to seriously regret asking, but what the hell are you doing?” demanded Malfoy’s voice, somewhat muffled by the woodwork. He sounded put out about something. Probably the bath hadn’t come pre-stocked with a loofah.

 

“First-year timetables,” I responded honestly, forgetting in my distraction who I was talking to.

 

A pause. “The timetables McGonagall already did for us, you mean.”

 

“No — well, yes — extra notes and things — directions to their lessons — which portraits to ask if they get lost.” I finished drawing the mini-map to the Astronomy Tower and added a small smiley-face next to it, then pulled the next sheet of paper toward me, scanning it over.

 

Divination? Bloody hell. Here was a clear lost cause already. Were we even allowed to take that before third year?

 

“I was forgetting.” Malfoy’s voice echoed faintly off the tiled walls of the bath, and I could practically hear his lip curling in derision. “Our resident swot and resident kiss-arse are one and the same.”

 

I drummed my fingertips against my lower lip, unperturbed by this accusation. Of all the things that could be said about him — and that is a very wide margin to be pushing, mind — one of them is that he’s not much of a liar. Draco Malfoy rarely speaks anything but the truth, even if he does often like to embellish it, to make it sound more, or less, insulting (depending on the target of said embellishment.)

 

So is it my fault if I like to expand my education and get on well with people at the same time? At least I don’t mean it to seem insincere.

 

“Shut up, Malfoy,” I suggested serenely, shuffling together the stack of completed time-tables, and leaned back against the couch cushions with a contented sigh.

 

Then I did a horrified Double-take of Horror at the closed bathroom door and repeated more forcefully, “Oh my Go — shut up, Malfoy! You are in the bath!”

 

Naked Malfoy. Wet, naked Malfoy. In close proximity to myself. Wet, naked Malfoy in close proximity to myself with Po’s face on my bum.

 

Scandalised to an impossible degree, I scooped up the pile of timetables and retreated to my bedroom before Malfoy could reply or indeed witness any of the bum-flap features for himself.

 

~*~

Eleven-seventeen p.m.

 

How in the name of Buddha’s loincloth did I ever manage to accumulate so much bad karma? I can’t recall running puppies over on my bicycle, eating small children for breakfast, setting fire to the neighbours’ shrubbery…

 

Maybe I really do have multiple personalities. Maybe they get to go round having all the naughty fun and Hermione Granger is the one that’s got to pay for all the others’ evil doings?

 

I wonder what their names are…

 

Filch stopped his lurching progress through the corridors quite suddenly, forcing Malfoy to draw up short ahead of me. I failed to notice this in time, and walked face-first into his back instead.

 

“Owbuggerfuck!”

 

Malfoy threw me a disdainful look over his shoulder.

 

“Honestly, Granger, it’s not hard,” he insisted. “You just put one foot in front of the other until you’ve got where you want to go, and then you stop. The trick is to not fall over during. Look, I’ll show you — ”

 

“This is it,” Filch interrupted, gesturing to the door in front of us with a grubby brass plaque on it marked ‘BROOM CUPBOARD #57.’

 

“What?” I stared at him through watering eyes, my fingertips pressing on the bridge of my nose to keep it from falling off.

 

“What?” Malfoy echoed, his smirk sliding away in his confusion.

 

“I said, this door here’s yours,” Filch repeated, grin widening and eyes narrowing accordingly. “Pleasant night,” he added, before shambling off through a nearby hidden passageway.

 

“But it says ‘broom cupboard fifty-seven’,” I murmured to no one in particular, blinking disbelievingly.

 

“Heavens, it’s a relief you can read or we might have stood out here all night,” Malfoy remarked, but his usual rancour was lacking. Instead he was studying the door in interest, running his fingers over the hinges and along the seam between door and frame.

 

I frowned at the back of his head. “Most people find giving the knob a twist often does the trick, you know.”

 

“Shut up,” he suggested passively, then declared, taking a step backward, “This isn’t a cupboard. The hinges aren’t real.”

 

“What are you on about?” I demanded in mystification, then pushed him aside to have a look for myself. The hinges looked real enough to me, felt real — my fingers didn’t go through them, at any rate — but then I realised suddenly what he meant. There were no joints and the screws were fused to the rest of the mounting; these hinges were just iron wrought to look like hinges, lacking their actual function.

 

“Well, what bloody use is that?” I wondered aloud, stunned.

 

“Iris root?” Malfoy ventured.

 

“Beg pardon? Oh.”

 

The missing hinge-joints had materialised at Malfoy’s words. I reached out and turned the handle experimentally. The door swung open without so much as a creak.

 

Inside — was a broom cupboard. Complete with brooms, a bucket and shelves of dusty bottles, sponges and steel wool.

 

“Iris root again?” Malfoy tried hopefully.

 

A broom fell over.

 

“I’ve had about enough of this,” I muttered impatiently, marching inside the narrow cupboard. I kicked the errant broom out of my way and started to push aside bottles of toilet cleaner and cartons thick with dust, hoping to find a trick-switch or a hidden stairwell or something.

 

“Get out of the way, Granger, you’ll never find it like that,” Malfoy ordered imperiously, striding in after me.

 

“No, you get out of — ” My voice broke off on a startled squeak; the door had just slammed shut behind him, as if of its own volition. The cupboard went abruptly dark as pitch.

 

A beat passed.

 

“Did you — ?” I began, a bit shrilly.

 

“No,” Malfoy’s voice replied grimly above my head. It wasn’t an especially roomy broom cupboard; I could feel him standing a few inches away in the dark space, even if he was somehow managing effectively not to touch any single part of me with any single part of himself.

 

“Oh.” I shrank against the shelves at my back, just in case. A pause. “Then what did you — ”

 

“I didn’t do anything.” I heard him rattle the door-handle. Nothing happened. He cursed.

 

I am NOT stuck in a broom cupboard with Draco Malfoy this is just too absurd for words I’m going to have to write us both detention slips for this and WHAT will the prefects think —

 

I swallowed my panic. “Well, you had to’ve done something — “

 

“Shut up.”

 

“You — look, don’t keep telling me to shut up, Malfoy! I didn’t ask for this either, you know — ”

 

“I mean stop making noise, if it pleases Her Highness. Can’t you hear that?”

 

I fell silent, ears straining. Then I did hear it. A low rumbling noise, getting louder… and the sound of whistling air. There was a metallic ringing, like a bicycle bell, and then the wall of shelves I was leaning on slid away in a huge cloud of dust, pale light streaming through the motes.

 

For a heart-stopping moment, I teetered on the edge of the yawning space behind me, arms pin-wheeling. Yelping a loud curse, I leapt forward, tripped, and fell directly onto Malfoy instead. He must have been too stunned to notice, or he likely would’ve pushed me right back into the hole.

 

As the haze cleared, a dimly-lit lift box became visible; old-fashioned with a metal grille that closed across the front of it. It was lined with carved wood panels and threadbare red velvet. Generic shopping mall music played lowly from invisible speakers.

 

What fresh hell.

 

“I, for one, wouldn’t mind sleeping at some point tonight. In a bed if at all possible,” came Malfoy’s pointed drawl at my back. Clearly he wasn’t nearly as stunned by all this as I was.

 

I shot him a frown, but pushed aside the grille obligingly, stepping into the lift box with caution. It felt sturdy enough under my weight, despite its ancient appearance.

 

Malfoy shut the grille loudly behind him, then leaned his shoulder-blades against the wall opposite myself, folding his arms and looking everywhere but at me. Which was fine, because I wasn’t looking at him either.

 

The lift shuddered ominously, then jerked once and began its comparatively smooth journey upward.

 

~*~

Nine-forty-seven p.m.

 

Sorting as equally uneventful as our arrival. A fine group of young lads and ladies, Dumbledore said. Some cracking candidates for next year’s Quidditch roster, Harry said. Snotty little titches, Ron said.

 

He’s not wrong, actually, their faces are essentially coated in the stuff. Where in the name of France have they been keeping it all?

 

Dumbledore’s welcome-back speech given. New DADA master introduced: one C. M. Youngblood, apparently dreadful late in arriving, and as of yet nowhere to be seen.

 

Polite applause all round. Nothing but the usual rigmarole.

 

Pulled aside for “brief prefect conference” in the middle of the post-Sorting feast. Slightly put out, because now all the treacle would be gone.

 

All four Heads of House present. Pleasantries exchanged. Progress reports of summer homework given. Cool stares stared.

 

Snape’s feelings towards me have not changed one whit over the summer months, I see; I still claim he is secretly petitioning to have me deported, but who will listen?

 

Discussed usual expectations as peer-leaders of our school (patrol hallways, curb rule-breaking, unstick first years from ceiling, etc.) and given this term’s dormitory passwords. The Fat Lady’s? ‘Yaffleblart’.

 

Am severely troubled. Is it possible for a painting to be mentally unbalanced?

 

Worst fears were also confirmed, just to make a real evening of it:

 

“Oh, and Mr Malfoy, Miss Granger — a moment, please,” Professor McGonagall finished, gesturing with two fingers. Not those two fingers, obviously.

 

“The password to the head dormitory is ‘iris root’,” she told us in a low tone, while Malfoy and myself contrived to stand as far apart from one another as was physically possible without actually being in separate rooms. I was rather having to strain to hear her.

 

“Meet in the Entrance Hall at eleven p.m. after your patrolling duties,” she went on, shuffling her papers into order and apparently choosing not to notice that neither of us would get within ten feet of her. “Mr Filch will be waiting to show you to the entrance.”

 

That gave me pause. I did not want to find myself anywhere near the Entrance Hall if Malfoy was going to be there.

 

I sidled up to McGonagall as the rest of the prefects were filing back out into the Great Hall — just in time for pudding, too, if the sheer level of noise coming through the door was any indication. Theirs was a genuinely impressive volume, one that could only ever be achieved by twenty-eight eleven-year-olds on a sugar high.

 

I muttered to her out of the corner of my mouth, “A word, Professor?”

 

“What is it, Miss Granger?”

 

I donned my best ‘Shame-on-you’ face.

 

“Is it really necessary for our sweet old Mr Filch to take us to the dormitory? He must be so dreadfully busy with… with the floors and the… walls. I mean, we’ve been at this school for nearly seven years now, I doubt if I won’t be able to find the entrance myself with just a bit of verbal direction.”

 

McGonagall’s eyebrows beetled suspiciously. Damn! I knew it was going too far, implying that our school caretaker actually took care of anything.

 

“It is not so easy to find as you presume, Miss Granger, and that is the main rationale behind its location. You have the first years’ timetables?”

 

I nodded mutely, heart sinking.

 

“Then you may join your classmates for the remainder of the feast and I shall see you in lessons tomorrow,” McGonagall said dismissively.

 

I blinked, then looked down at the sheaf of papers in my hand, and I blinked at them too. Had I just been brushed off?

 

Professors never brush me off!

 

“What did I do to you people?” I demanded feebly, but a bewildered McGonagall was saved from answering when the door swung open without warning.

 

The noise poured in again as an unfamiliar woman stepped inside, then cut off once more when she shut the door behind her, shaking rain off her cloak.

 

“Ah, yes,” McGonagall commented in a business-like tone, clearly recognising the visitor, and gestured a second time towards the door. “Miss Granger? Tomorrow?” she repeated pointedly.

 

Feeling wounded to the deepest depths of my core, I stalked out of the room.

 

~*~

 

Eleven-oh-two p.m.

 

Truly amaze self sometimes. Fantasize about running away and marrying self sometimes.

 

Well? They almost let Aberforth Dumbledore marry that goat, why not someone with multiple-personality disorder?

 

Managed all of the following in under thirty-seven minutes:

·         herded goats — er, I mean first-years up to Gryffindor Tower (without losing even a single one on the way, I’ll add, though a rogue moving-staircase nearly spoiled my perfect record)

·         pointed out helpful landmarks en route, so first years will be able to find their way back down for breakfast tomorrow morning

·         organized buddy system for when above-mentioned plan inevitably fudges

·         sorted out trunks having been put on wrong floor

·         sent owls home for students who left toothbrushes/contact lens cases/teddy bears behind

·         located lost cat

·         mopped up said cat’s wee from carpet

·         circumvented murder attempt when Crookshanks mistook this for territory claim

 

After all of which, I still had time to:

·     round up on-duty prefects for quick race through upper floor corridors

·     send to bed any post-Feast revellers still straggling behind

·     suss out of broom cupboards any couples celebrating their reunion in rather exploratory ways

·     give chase to anyone unwilling to accept detention slips graciously

 

Which made me really, really out of breath, sort of impressed at some people’s stamina, and only two minutes late to meet Filch in the Entrance Hall at eleven.

 

If I hadn’t been so upset that the dreaded Inevitable Moment had finally arrived, I would have found a spare moment to pat myself on the back. As it were…

 

“Our Saint Granger — tardy!” Filch deplored with an awful grin, as I came to a panting halt a few feet away from where he and Malfoy stood waiting.

 

“Sorry,” I puffed, bending double and adding breathlessly in Malfoy’s direction, “Your mate Zabini is a lot quicker on his feet than I remember. Does he do marathons for fun or something?”

 

~*~

 

Eleven-oh-seven­­ p.m.

 

Why are raving old men so horrid? There must be a sort of invisible inner switch that trips once they reach a certain age, and then they wake up one morning, completely off their nut and thinking, “Jolly good day for harassing school-age girls and coughing on people.”

These two individuals really believe that this is a “soothing, meditative practise, really brings us back to the days of Orient,” (said the single mother from Brighton) and that it’s of some real use towards the ”common good”.

 

All I was able to glean from the fifteen-minute-long segment was that starving people could care less about bits of coloured paper folded to vaguely resemble animals. You can’t eat paper. Well, you can, but not to any great effect. You can’t make it grow better crops or cause the rain to fall.

 

And that’s when it happened. I realised, with a sudden burst of clarity, that I am not a starving Ethiopian.

 

Far bloody from it… the other day Mum actually tore her eyes away from her second child — I mean, from her dissertation, long enough to recall my existence in this house, and all she had to offer me was a close squint and some remark about taking me bra shopping before I left. Honestly. Is it so hard for people to focus their attention elsewhere?

 

Anyway. Back to why I do have a reason for living, after all.

 

My future, albeit somewhat cringe-making, is not an outright uncertainty. I will wake up tomorrow morning, healthy and warm and without some mad, sunburnt bint flapping a paper frog in my face.

 

Well. Never say never.

 

I mean, yes, there is the depressingly good chance I will spend the next ten months of my life feeling wretched and out of sorts and inexplicably angry, but that’s what being seventeen — God, almost eighteen — is all about, isn’t it? It must be written somewhere that girls my age have to be miserable now, or else we’ll never survive our Golden Years.

 

Mum threw her slipper at me when I presented her with this theory. I fear she may be jealous of my initiative.

 

So. Dreadful, horrible, awful news be damned. I am determined to lose no sleep over it.

Why Nobody Will Ever Paint an Eyebrow-less Portrait of Hermione Granger, Thank God:

An Inside Look:

A Diary

August 20th

Six-twenty p.m.

 

Dear Diary,

 

Well, bugger this for a lark.

 

The inconceivable, absolute worst has happened. Actually.

 

“It” has happened. The “It” we have been preparing for — sooo woefully unprepared! — all summer long. The dark, ugly stain upon our pretty, bright horizon.

 

Well. His complexion is rather fair, and if I’m being honest it’s hardly an ordeal to look at him, as I recall, provided he’s not trying to Stare Somebody Down. I wonder if he knows how constipated that makes him look.

 

I would guess no.

 

Professor McGonagall has been warning me for years this might happen. Money has influence, she’s always said, even if it did used to be with a squint like she was staring directly into the sun.

 

But I stand firm by my own resolve. I am a strong believer that clear-headed logic and simple determination still have their own sway in this steadily crumbling world.

 

I don’t mean this steadily crumbling world; I mean the go-to-school-in-a-castle, wave-a-wand-about-and-get-a-sparkle, for-the-love-of-God-don’t-tell-the-neighbours world.

 

The world with Scrimgeour acting like a pompous, self-gratifying boor (that’s just on weekends, though, the rest of the time he’s Minister for Magic… amazingly, yes, there is a difference.)

 

The world with Curious Happenings and bubbling cauldrons and unfair points systems which are demeaning to a young person’s sense of worth, but supposedly build character and a healthy taste for competition. The one with more books than I ever thought possible, some of which have been known to kill (a double-existence I’ve never been able to come to terms with.)

 

Perhaps it is the teenager in me. Perhaps I have been spending too much time indoors, alone, befriending a ruffled notebook.

 

Perhaps I am right, actually, and no single, innocent (when you disregard school years one-and-a-half through six, innocent) seventeen-year-old girl should have to undergo this much trauma all on her own.

 

Perhaps I will just go eat some of the pie Mum’s brought home…

 

~*~

 

August 22nd

Three-forty-three p.m.

 

Dear Diary,

 

Received the second of Dumbledore’s letters today. Shall transcribe the horror forthwith:

 

Dear Miss Granger,

 

In response to your unexpected response, I remark only on your incredible reaction to what I had supposed you would find pleasing news. I assure you, the information you received was not a cruel joke at your expense, illegally tampered with en route, or otherwise “copied out wrong”: going into your seventh year at Hogwarts, based upon academic achievement, services done in the name of the school, and a vote taken amongst the staff and myself, it is with great pride (and puzzlement) that I announce, now for the second time, this year’s head boy and girl. They are, respectively, Mr Draco Malfoy and yourself, Miss Hermione Granger.

 

That said, I detected a definite tone of distress in your recent missive. Has the administration spelled your name incorrectly?

 

Yours in amiable confusion,

 

Albus, etc. Dumbledore

Headmaster

 

I read it three more times before I had to go have a soothing lie down. When it still said the same thing an hour later, I had no choice but to burn it. Just as I did the first one.

 

Scattering their ashes to the fourwinds might have been taking things a bit far, though, now I come to think of it. Especially as I had to walk all the way to the South End to find a decent breeze, and Mr. Harris the alderman had a right strop when some of it got in his beard.

 

Anyway, really wish I hadn’t done that, because now I’ve begun to wonder if anyone will believe me, at least until they’ve seen it for their own eyes. After all, I’d got the proof right in front of me and I still couldn’t believe it.

 

Writing to Dumbledore again and asking him to forward a copy of his letters to all my friends probably wouldn’t go over very well.

 

I told my mum, but as predicted, she was little help. She’s been writing that thesis for ages — I tried to get just a speck of sympathy from her, tried to convey to her the very real profoundness of my misery; and all I got in return was her raving on for England about the calcium imbalances in the average Briton’s diet and the apparent adverse effects this has on our dental industry.

 

“The people have to know!” she informs me, quite regularly. With extra exclamation points sometimes.

 

Dad is no better.

 

“Hang on, darling, which slimy tosser do you mean?  Is this the one with the halitosis or the one with nicer writing than you?”

 

I could send letters, desperate pleas for help, to Harry and Ron. I probably will, too, once I’m able to rise from my bed of despair long enough to grasp a pen.

 

They likely won’t write back, though, what with Harry just trying to keep a hold on what vestiges of sanity he’s got left during his last summer in Privet Drive, and Ron with his fourteen girlfriends.

 

Still. They might send cakes. Boys show sympathy in sugary ways I will never comprehend, but can appreciate nevertheless.

 

Oh goodness, I had better not be getting fat on top of everything else.

 

~*~

 

August 23rd

Two-twelve a.m.

 

Dear Diary,

 

I’ve cracked it!

 

I shall stage a protest. I’ve done them before, with a fair amount of success. No technical results, per se, but I think escaping arrest is a just victory for all.

 

I could even re-use some of my old signs from the S.P.E.W. campaign.

 

‘SAY “NO” TO UNFAIR OPPRESSION OF MAGICAL CREATURES WITHOUT INFLUENCE OVER THEIR OWN SOCIOECONOMIC WELL-BEING!’ might actually be a little wordy, in retrospect, but if I cut out an adjective or two I think I could make it work.

 

Quite a large sign. Difficult to hold upright, if memory serves.

 

Perhaps I should find a prop-stick. Er…
